INFO.NAME: Glossary

ENTRY.DEFINITION:
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;"></p><p>Coverage is a feature that acts as a function to return values from its range for 
any direct position within its spatial, temporal or spatiotemporal 
domain. [Source: ISO 19123:2005, 4.1.7]<br></p><p>Coverages are represented by some binary or ASCII serialization, specified by some data (en­coding) format. Arguably the most popular type of coverage is that of a gridded 
coverage. Gridded coverages have a grid as their domain set describing 
the direct positions in multi-dimensional coordinate space, depending on
 the type of grid. Satellite imagery is typically modelled as a gridded 
coverage, for example. [Source: https://ogcapi.ogc.org/coverages/]<br></p><p><br></p><br><p></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">Information describing spatial data sets and spatial data services and making it possible to discover, inventory and use them. <br></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: INSPIRE Directive article nº 3.6 https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2007:108:0001:0014:EN:PDF]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">It is a multi-part standard that offers the capability to create, 
modify, and query spatial data on the Web and specifies requirements and
 recommendations for APIs that want to follow a standard way of sharing 
feature data.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: https://ogcapi.ogc.org/features/]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">The OGC API - Joins draft standard specifies a Web API that allows data 
to be joined from supplied data files either with feature collections 
that are available on the server or directly with other provided files. 
The draft standard also defines functionalities for viewing general 
metadata on the service implementation, metadata and key values on the 
feature collections and functionalities for accessing and deleting the 
created joins.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: https://ogcapi.ogc.org/joins/]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">OGC API - Records is a multi-part draft specification that offers the capability to
                                    create, modify, and query metadata on the Web. The draft specification enables the
                                    discovery of geospatial resources by standardizing the way collections of
                                    descriptive information about the resources (metadata) are exposed. The draft
                                    specification also enables the discovery and sharing of related resources that may
                                    be referenced from geospatial resources or their metadata by standardizing the way
                                    all kinds of records are exposed and managed. Part 1 will cover read-only access to
                                    records and simple query capabilities. Additional capabilities that address specific
                                    needs will be specified in additional parts. Capabilities for richer queries or to
                                    create, update or delete records will be specified in additional parts.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: https://ogcapi.ogc.org/records/]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">The OGC API - Processes standard supports the wrapping of computational tasks into
                                    executable processes that can be offered by a server through a Web API and be
                                    invoked by a client application. The standard specifies a processing interface to
                                    communicate over a RESTful protocol using JavaScript Object Notation (JSON)
                                    encodings. Typically, these processes execute well-defined algorithms that ingest
                                    vector and/or coverage data to produce new datasets.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"><br></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: https://ogcapi.ogc.org/processes/]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">OGC API - Coverages allows discovery, visualization and query of complex raster stacks and data cubes. It draft specification defines a Web API for 
accessing coverages that are modeled according to the Coverage 
Implementation Schema (CIS) 1.1. Coverages are represented by some 
binary or ASCII serialization, specified by some data (en­coding) 
format. Arguably the most popular type of coverage is that of a gridded 
coverage. Gridded coverages have a grid as their domain set describing 
the direct positions in multi-dimensional coordinate space, depending on
 the type of grid. Satellite imagery is typically modeled as a gridded 
coverage, for example.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: https://ogcapi.ogc.org/coverages/]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"></p><p>The OGC API family of standards are being developed to make it easy 
for anyone to provide geospatial data to the web. These standards build 
upon the legacy of the OGC Web Service standards (WMS, WFS, WCS, WPS, 
etc.), but define resource-centric APIs that take advantage of modern 
web development practices. This web page provides information on these 
standards in a consolidated location.</p><p>These standards are being constructed as "building blocks" that can 
be used to assemble novel APIs for web access to geospatial content. The
 building blocks are defined not only by the requirements of the 
specific standards, but also through interoperability prototyping and 
testing in OGC's Innovation Program.</p><p>[Source: https://ogcapi.ogc.org/]</p><br><p></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">The Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC), an international voluntary consensus standards organization, originated in 1994. In the OGC, more than 500 commercial, governmental, nonprofit and research organizations collaborate in a consensus process encouraging the development and implementation of open standards for geospatial content and services, sensor web and Internet of Things, GIS data processing and data sharing.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Geospatial_Consortium]<br></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"><br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"></p><p>The Uniform Resource Locator (URL) or hyperlink is a string that 
provides a reference to a resource on the Web. A Web resource can be 
anything: a page, file, image, or as explained below an HTTP GET 
request. Some examples are as follows:</p><ul><li><p><a href="http://www.opengeospatial.org/">http://www.opengeospatial.org</a></p></li><li><p><a href="ftp://ftp.funet.fi/pub/standards/RFC/rfc959.txt">ftp://ftp.funet.fi/pub/standards/RFC/rfc959.txt</a></p></li><li><p>Mailto:&nbsp;<a href="mailto:standards-team%40ogc.org">standards-team@ogc.org</a></p></li></ul><p>The first identifies and provides access to the OGC website. The 
second identifies and provides access to a text-only document and the 
third one identifies and provides access to an email address.</p><p></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: http://opengeospatial.github.io/e-learning/fundamental-concepts/text/networking.html#url]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"></p><p>Encodings provide the format (arrangement of data elements) and 
syntax of the data and messages, or data send to and by a server.</p><p>Messages are files or data streams. The format identifies and 
determines what type of computer program can be used to read or interact
 with the file or data stream. For example:</p><blockquote><div><ul><li><p>A file in XML requires a program that can read XML.</p></li><li><p>An image in JPG requires a program that can read JPG images.</p></li><li><p>A temporary binary object in JAVA requires a Java program that can understand this type of object.</p></li></ul></div></blockquote><p>Web Services operate through interfaces and operations that allow the exchange of information with certain encodings.</p>[Source: http://opengeospatial.github.io/e-learning/fundamental-concepts/text/networking.html#encodings]<br><p></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">In the context of Web services, an operation is a request to a server. For example,
an HTTP GET request is a specific operation. An operation is defined by a service interface.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: http://opengeospatial.github.io/e-learning/fundamental-concepts/text/networking.html#operation]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">A collection of entries, each of which describes and points to a feature
 collection. Catalogs include indexed listings of feature collections, 
their contents, their coverages, and other metadata. Registers the 
existence, location, and description of feature collections held by an 
Information Community. Catalogs provide the capability to add and delete
 entries. At a minimum Catalog will include the name for the feature 
collection and the locational handle that specifies where this data may 
be found. The means by which an Information Community advertises its 
holdings to members of the Information Community and to the rest of the 
world. Each catalog is unique to its Information Community.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">[Source: https://www.ogc.org/ogc/glossary/c]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">A software component that can invoke an operation performed by a server.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">[Source: https://www.ogc.org/ogc/glossary/c]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"><span lang="EN-GB">Transformers
are the building blocks for your FME data transformation workflows. Each
transformer has a specific function, and when combined, can be used to create
powerful integration workspaces.</span><br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;"><span xml:lang="en-gb" lang="en-gb">Feature
Manipulation Engine. The platform on which our Quality Software is built.</span><br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;"><span xml:lang="en-gb" lang="en-gb">GitHub
is a code hosting platform that contains our Quality Software and other
related documents.</span></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;"><span lang="EN-GB">See
more: </span><span lang="ES"><a href="https://github.com/"><span lang="EN-GB">https://github.com/</span></a></span><br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;"><span xml:lang="en-gb" lang="en-gb">CityGML
is an open standardised data model and exchange format for storing digital 3D
models of cities and landscapes. The format is used in the our Quality
Software.</span><br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"><span lang="EN-GB">ETL
(Extract, Transform, Load) is a data integration process that extracts (usually
heterogenous) data from multiple sources, combines and transforms them into a
single entity, and loads data into the database or another data repository.</span><br></p>
The Application Programming Interface (API) is a set of functions, procedures, definitions and protocols for machine-to-machine communication and the seamless exchange of data.

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">An identifiable collection of data [ISO 19115-1].<br></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">See more:&nbsp;<a href="https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/DataSet"><span lang="EN-GB">https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/DataSet</span></a></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">High-Value Datasets (HVD) means documents the re-use of which is associated with important benefits for society, the environment and the economy, in particular because of their suitability for the creation of value-added services, applications, new, high-quality jobs, and of the number of potential beneficiaries of the value-added services and applications based on those datasets.</p><p>See more: <span lang="PT"><a href="https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32019L1024&amp;from=EN">Directive EU2019/1024</a> and <a href="https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32023R0138&amp;from=EN">Regulation (EU) 2023/138</a></span><span lang="ES"><a href="https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=CELEX:32023R0138&amp;from=EN"><span lang="PT"></span></a></span><span lang="PT"></span></p><br><p></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">Any data with a direct or indirect reference to a specific location or geographical area [INSPIRE Directive, Art. 3].<br></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">See more:&nbsp;<a href="https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/SpatialData">https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/SpatialData</a></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"><br></p>

<p dir="ltr">A View Service is a service making it possible to display, navigate, zoom in/out, pan, or overlay viewable spatial data sets and to display legend information and any relevant metadata content [INSPIRE Directive, Art. 11].</p><p dir="ltr">Examples: WMS or WMTS</p><p>See more:&nbsp;<a href="https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/ViewService">https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/ViewService</a></p>

<p dir="ltr"><span style="font-size:0.9375rem;">A Download Service is a service enabling copies of spatial data sets, or parts of such sets, to be downloaded, and, where practicable, accessed directly [INSPIRE Directive, Art. 11].</span><br></p><p dir="ltr">Examples: WFS or ATOM Feed</p><p dir="ltr">See more:&nbsp;<span lang="en-gb" xml:lang="en-gb"><a href="https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/DownloadService" title="https://inspire.ec.europa.eu/glossary/DownloadService">Download Service</a></span></p><p><br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">The landing page is the top-level resource that serves as an entry 
point. A client application needs to know the location of the landing 
page of the server. From the landing page, the client application can 
then retrieve links to the Conformance declaration, Collection and API 
definition paths.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">[Source: http://opengeospatial.github.io/e-learning/ogcapi-features/text/operations.html]<br /></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"></p><p>Conformance refers to a resource that identifies the specifications that the link’s context conforms to.<strong><br></strong></p><p>[Source: <a href="https://defs.opengis.net/vocprez/object?uri=http%3A//www.opengis.net/def/rel/ogc/1.0/conformance">https://defs.opengis.net/vocprez/object?uri=http%3A//www.opengis.net/def/rel/ogc/1.0/conformance</a>]<strong><br></strong></p><br><p></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"></p><p>Collection
 is a geospatial resource that may be available as one or more 
sub-resource distributions that conform to one or more OGC API 
standards. OGC APIs typically organize their Spatial Resources into 
collections.</p><p>[Source: <a href="http://docs.ogc.org/DRAFTS/20-024.html#collections-metadata0">http://docs.ogc.org/DRAFTS/20-024.html#collections-metadata</a>]</p><br><p></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;"></p><p>pygeoapi is a Python library for server implementation of the OGC API suite of standards.</p><br><p></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">GeoServer is a Java-based server that allows users to view and edit geospatial data, for example, by using OGC API standards.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;"><a href="https://geoserver.org/">Link to Geoserver website</a><br></p>
<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">Tile is a smaller subset of geographical data set. <br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is a lightweight data-interchange 
format that is commonly used for transmitting data between web services.
 OGC APIs use JSON to encode the data that is exchanged between the API 
server and the client.<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">Representational State Transfer (REST) is an architectural style for 
building web APIs. OGC APIs are based on the REST architectural style, 
which defines a set of constraints and best practices for designing and 
implementing web APIs.<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">YAML is a data serialization language. It is commonly used for 
configuration files and in applications where data is being stored or 
transmitted. YAML stands for "YAML Ain't Markup Language", and is a 
human-readable, high-level programming language for representing data in
 a hierarchical and structured format. YAML is often used in place of 
XML or JSON, because it is more concise and easier to read and write.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">In the context of OGC APIs, YAML is often used as a configuration language for defining the structure and properties of
 an OGC API. For example, it can define the parameters, resources and metadata of an API.<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) defines a standard, language-agnostic 
interface to RESTful APIs which allows both humans and computers to 
discover and understand the capabilities of the service without access 
to source code, documentation, or through network traffic inspection. 
When properly defined, a consumer can understand and interact with the 
remote service with a minimal amount of implementation logic. OGC APIs use this specification.<br></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">[Source: https://swagger.io/specification/]<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">OGC APIs use a RESTful (Representational State Transfer) architecture, 
which means that they use HTTP methods (such as GET, POST, PUT, and 
DELETE) to retrieve and manipulate resources over the web. This enables 
users to access and manipulate resources in a standard, predictable way.</p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">OGC APIs are designed to work with open data, which means that the data 
and services they access are freely available to use, reuse, and 
redistribute. This aligns with the FAIR principles, which aim to make 
data and other digital resources more Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable. <br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">European Data Portal (EDP) gathers Public Sector Information that can be freely reused for any 
purpose (i.e. Open Data) of the 28 European Member States and the four 
EFTA countries. On the portal, only metadata is shown, which is directly
 harvested from the existing portals with the aim of providing one 
single access point to all this data.</p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;"><a href="https://data.europa.eu/fi">Link to European Data Portal</a><br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">A standard is a document that has been officially 
adopted or approved as a guideline or specification for a particular 
technology or industry. Standards are typically developed by industry 
groups, government agencies, or other organizations with expertise in a 
specific field (e.g. Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) or International Organization for Standardization (ISO)) and are intended to promote consistency, safety, and 
interoperability. <br /></p><p dir="ltr" style="text-align:left;">For example, ISO 19157 establishes the principles for describing the quality of geographic data<br /></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">UML (Unified Modeling Language) is a graphical language used to model 
and describe the design of a system, including its components and the 
relationships between them. UML diagrams can be used to model a wide 
range of systems, including software systems, business processes, and 
physical systems.<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">DCAT-AP (Data Catalog Vocabulary - Application Profile) is an extension 
of the Data Catalog Vocabulary (DCAT) which is an RDF vocabulary for 
describing datasets and data catalogs on the web. DCAT-AP is a 
specification that defines how to use DCAT to describe datasets and data
 catalogs in the context of the European Union. It provides a common 
data model and a set of classes and properties that can be used to 
describe datasets and their associated metadata.<br></p>

<p dir="ltr" style="text-align: left;">Service architecture refers to the design and organization of the 
components and services that make up a system or application. It 
describes how the different services and components interact and 
communicate with each other, and how they are organized and deployed. 
Service architecture also includes the development of the service 
interfaces, the design of the data flows, and the orchestration of the 
services. It helps to ensure that a system is scalable, maintainable, 
and can evolve over time to meet changing business needs.<br></p>
